 Rakove shows how Madison developed a variety of political concepts to solve the problem of majority tyranny. Turning conventional wisdom on its head, Madison argued - first in his 1787 essay "Vices of the Political System of the United States," and later in his famous Federalist 10 - that liberty would be safer in a large Republic (the size of the United States) than in a small republic (the size of a state). There would be such a multiplicity of interests in a large republic that no single self-interested faction would be able to forge a tyrannical majority. Instead, various interests would cancel each other out, allowing the public good and minority rights to prevail. An extended republic, moreover, would enjoy the benefits of a "filtration of talent," as larger electoral districts would result in the election of wiser and more far-sighed leaders than the narrowminded men who found their way into the state legislatures.

 Turning to the self-defense case. At first glance, before I read the Cornell article, I admit it was tempting to argue that one case is a very small cherry pulled from a much larger tree, and that one case involving a couple of trial dog lawyers does not a quorum make. However, Cornell does argue that this case involved the "leading legal minds of the day," and I have no reason to dispute this. So I looked into the actual arguments Cornell cited. Having done so it is my opinion-agree or disagree as you will-that Cornell completely misses the legal issue, and that when properly understood it does not support his case. 
 
 I would first note that this case does not address the 2nd. Amendment at all, for it was unquestioned at that time (the suppositions about Madison's views in the article cited above notwithstanding) the BoR applied exclusively as a bar to federal action, while this was a state court prosecution involving state laws. Therefore, it was only the Pennsylvania Constitution's RKBA provision which was potentially an issue. Nevertheless, I believe Cornell tries to use this case as a cutting out expedition to divorce the Pennsylvania RKBA provision from the individual right of armed self-defense-no doubt with an aim to later making a similar claim against the 2nd. Amendment. 
 
 But here is where I believe Cornell displays his lack of understanding of legal arguments....Cornell argues that "nether side believed that the use of a gun for personal self defense had any connection to the constitutional right to bear arms protected by the Pennsylvania Constitution." Now I have not read the transcript, and so admittedly Cornell has me at a disadvantage-I must rely entirely on the information he cites for his claim. Yet as far as I can see he arrives at this conclusion not by any direct evidence-no quotations from the transcript, for example. Rather, he argues in the negative-the transcript apparently shows that neither side argued over the wording of the RKBA provision, but they instead focused a great deal of time on their arguments over the proper scope of the common law right of self-defense. In my opinion Cornell clearly wants us to believe that the reason why the RKBA provision was not debated was because it must have nothing at all to do with private self-defense. 
 
 But let me put the actual wording of the Pennsylvania RKBA provision (as adopted on August 16, 1776) to a more candid audience: 
 
 That the people have a right to bear arms for the defense of themselves and the state; And as standing armies in the time of peace are dangerous to liberty, they ought not to be kept up; And that the military should be kept under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power. (emphasis added by me)
 
 Can anyone here argue with a straight face that the highlighted language does not recognize a right of individual self-defense? Yet Cornell would have us believe that not just a first year law student but the "leading legal minds of the day" would miss the obvious argument-that the words "the people have a right to bear arms for the defense of themselves" meant their client had a constitutional right to act in self-defense?
 
 Come back to the case Cornell cites. The argument is not made because it was not required to be made. If the prosecution had argued that the defendant had no right to act in self-defense at all, then the "leading legal minds of the day" representing the defendant would have had to argue the obvious-the RKBA provision enshrines this very right. From what I can see they never had to cite the RKBA provision to make this argument because the prosecution conceded that the defendant had a right to act in self-defense. When you look at the arguments that Cornell cites from both sides, the issue is clearly not whether the defendant had a right to act in self-defense but whether his claim to have acted in self-defense was justified. Cornell glosses over this fact. 
 
 Cornell's supposition is also flawed because, in my opinion, it flows from a basic misunderstanding of the link between the common law right of self-defense and the RKBA provision. In my opinion he believes they are totally separate entities. But notice the RKBA provision only says "defense of themselves." It does not define what the right of self-defense is. It does not tell us, for example, under what circumstances the exercise of the right is justified, and under what circumstances it is not. 
 
 This is because it does not need to. And here is where Cornell demonstrates his fatal misunderstanding. He believes the RKBA provision created a separate right, and that the failure to claim this separate right means the defense team felt it did not create an individual right at all. But the Pennsylvania RKBA provision did not create a new and separate right, it only recognized and protected the common law right of armed self-defense that pre-existed the Pennsylvania Constitution which the defendant did claim-the very right the prosecution concedes when both sides argue what the scope of this right really is. Cornell fails to understand this, and so he fails to understand why the argument over the meaning of the RKBA provision did not take place. 
 
 And so my opinion is the lack of argument over the RKBA provision flows from an acknowledgement that there is no argument to make. And this happens far more often than you might think. For example, every case that involves a suppression hearing on a claim that evidence was seized in violation of the 4th. Amendment involves the threshold question of whether the person seeking to suppress the evidence had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place searched or the thing seized. For example, none of you live with me, and none of you has a right to complain that evidence was seized illegally from my house. But in almost every case this issue of who can make the 4th. Amendment violation claim is conceded up front. If, for example, drugs are seized from a car at a traffic stop, then we never waste time arguing that the owner/driver did or did not have an expectation of privacy in the contents of his car. We concede that issue and move on to the real issue-it is not about whether he had a 4th. Amendment right of privacy in the car, but whether the search of his car violated that right. 
 
 Cornell's lack of citing any argument to the contrary shows that the same is true in the case he mentions. The RKBA provision tells us that the defendant had a right to possess a firearm for the purpose of being prepared for armed self-defense. It also tells us that he had a right to use the firearm in armed self-defense. But these were not issues in the case. The question in this case is not whether he had a right to possess the firearm or even that he had a right to use it in self-defense. The question was whether he was really acting in self-defense. 
 
 And that, as the lawyers correctly argued in the case Cornell cites, is a matter of interpreting the nature and the scope of the common law right the RKBA provision protects. In exercising this protected right did the defendant have to retreat to the wall, or could he stand his ground before using or threatening the use of deadly force? Did the nature of the harm to him rise to a level that justified the use or threat of deadly force? These are all questions that are not answered by looking at the RKBA provision but by searching out the parameters of the common law right the RKBA provision protects. It is little wonder then that the "leading legal minds of the day" confined their arguments to the actual issue in the case, and it should not come as a surprise to an unbiased historian that an RKBA provision which was never an issue was not discussed. 
 
 But of course I am no recognized historian, and my biases for gun rights are admittedly well documented on this blog cite. I will say in my favor that I have far more experience in actually arguing the common law right of self-defense before a court than Cornell does. It is up to the reader to act as judge and determine which of us has the better argument....
